discourse_list.title: A Letter to the CUs on Community Impatience and Trust

content.content: I was reading through the Charting a Path For RWAs - The Case For Continuity post (a very detailed, informative, and well-written piece btw) and saw that the underlying message is a call for patience and trust.  I thought it was a great overarching vision that was presented of the future of MKR.  But in thinking more about it, I realized I wanted to add a little perspective to perhaps why there is a little bit of impatience in some of the proposals and the process of onboarding RWA.  I initially wrote this as a reply but it started to get a little off topic so I’m going to start a new topic on it.  1. Shifting Directions Maker got started on the back of investors who saw potential in using crypto native assets as collateral.  The promise was that smart contracts put in place would be able to create a super efficient lending system.  Profits would then be returned to token holders using the buyback and burn model.  This efficient lending system had some issues but it is largely in place with more safety measures having been added over time.  However, the return of capital to token holders has been done away with in the name of growth.  The argument for growth is understandable but it does represent a large shift in what was originally presented.  At the start, there was no surplus buffer.  Later the surplus buffer was meant to be used as a measure to reduce risk.  Now it is used to support growth.  All these changes may be understandable changes but there were plenty of controversies and for those who may not have been onboard as they were approved, there is a feeling of promises broken and frustration.  2. Unsustainable Rise in Operating Expenses Though real world assets certainly present a large opportunity, it also comes at the cost of a massive increase in operating expenses.  As has been stated, these transactions are messy and much more complicated than dealing with on chain collateral.  Because of this, core units are now justified to tack on huge legal costs, professional services, and increasing head counts to deal with these complexities.  These expenses are felt immediately and very visible in the sharp surplus buffer drops seen each month.  Because there is no global budget cap, it’s not clear how high these expenses will spiral to.  What’s clear is that current revenues are not keeping up with the expense increases.  Because there is no timeline for actual realization of revenue growth, what you are left with is impatience and a desire to onboard every collateral application in sight.  Everyone understands that each RWA transaction takes a lot of work and time to realize any value but frustration sets in when months pass with multiple RWA proposals stuck in RFC mode for various reasons.  Of course, not all proposals are made equal and particular attention will naturally be given to those that seem more promising.  If actual progress is made and highlighted, I believe much of this frustration will be alleviated.  3. Growing Perception of Greed and Waste There are four ways protocol profits flow.  Either to core units/delegates, dai holders through mechanisms like the DSR, building the surplus buffer, or back to MKR investors in the form of a buyback.  The aggressive growth strategy advocated for building a larger SB to increase tolerance for risk and ability to experiment.  Ok, for those who bought in, the desire is now to see the SB increase.  But as expenses increase, this can create a sense that core units are monopolizing the profits.  Beyond all the reasons of healthcare, inflation, competitive wages, the salaries and benefits just look high.  The travel, the admin expenses, the happiness perks.  They don’t have a look of frugality to them.  Every expense seems justified in the name of growth but taken together, it feels lavish.  Core units are not confronted with the question of what expense to prioritize.  They’re incentivized to cover all the bases and even build buffers for themselves in case of uncertainty.  I do believe there’s plenty of work being done and teams feel they still need more help but is it being done efficiently?  Is the right work being done?  Or does more manpower just result in more conflicts and arguments over who’s right and what we should be doing?  4. Centralized Voting Power How decentralized is MKR’s governance really?  Only 11.2% MKR or 109k MKR are being delegated.  Breaking things down further, we see 15.6k comes from one address, 15k from another, 10k from another, 8k from another, and 3k from 3 others.  That’s about 50k MKR delegated from 7 addresses.  Almost half of the voting power.  I have not even looked at all the delegates or added quite a few addresses delegating 1k MKR .  Additionally, we have 5.7k MKR vesting to core units annually which have the most incentive and savvy to put those MKR right to work and delegate to people who are on their side.  With such concentration of power, it’s understandable that your average MKR holder might feel disenfranchised.  I often read of an argument being made that if MKR holders don’t like the CUs decisions, they can vote them out.  But really, it’s the opinion of those seven MKR whales that matters. Edit: I may not understand how this works.  What I was looking at was this recognized delegates page. But I was directed to this link for MKR locked in governance which shows an even greater concentration of voting power.  5. CU Influence and Power Core units have a lot of power because they are paid to spend their time analyzing and crafting opinion pieces for their positions.  They have more time and a bigger voice to influence public opinion. They can support their own positions and crowd out critical opinions.  Those who lose faith drop out of the community and slowly the opposing voices fade away. Like it or not, from a general investor’s perspective holding MKR perhaps on an exchange, all these developments make it feel like there’s an us vs them mentality.  Without concrete deadlines, CUs could drag things out to their own benefit and even if we see growth…will that growth actually benefit a MKR holder?  Or does it just keep getting “reinvested” back into the protocol?  People generally have some kind of expectation for when results should be seen and if that expectation is not met, you will get frustration. This isn’t a post to criticize any of the RWA efforts.  The vision is a big one that I think many would be onboard with.  The question is whether MKR is headed in the right direction to accomplish it.  I truly believe there are very intelligent and passionate people working for this protocol and I don’t think anyone is trying to actively sabotage it.  I simply want the CUs to understand why patience is hard and hope this promotes efforts for more transparency, clarity, and accountability, ultimately to bring more trust between alienated MKR holders and CUs.

This efficient lending system had some issues but it is largely in place with more safety measures having been added over time. However, the return of capital to token holders has been done away with in the name of growth.   I can’t echo this enough… I know that aggressive growth is very valuable and necessary for a start-up company. Reinvesting into growing is what you do… but right now… it seems like we’ve done away with any revenue distribution model. Nothing specific in place to replace it. The narrative is broken, or at least… not clear. I understand why so many people who originally came here and dedicated years towards supporting Maker feel disenfranchised. I still see enormous promise and a massively bright future for Dai and MakerDAO, which makes me even sadder to see the state of things as they are right now.

content.content: Just to clarify, my intent is not to promote negativity about this project nor to disrupt the work that’s happening now.  I can’t say enough how much I appreciate the idea behind all the work that has been and continues to be done on this protocol.  I see the potential and the vision.  I see how this can transform, for the better, a very imperfect world.  And the fact that I could even learn enough to write this post and be allowed to write it shows there is a considerable amount of transparency and openness already here. My intent is mainly to present this case so that as decisions are made, those who have more power and influence can be cognizant of some of these issues causing frustration.  The best businesses take care of all stakeholders - customers, investors, employees.  Everyone grows and succeeds together.  The decision to pursue growth through a larger surplus buffer has been made and whether we agree or disagree, we should all move on together.  I just want to be kept abreast of how things are going so I can stay on the same page.  With the buy and burn model, it was easy to see MKR’s supply going down.  It was almost a real time status on how the protocol was performing.  We know that startup costs with RWAs are high and this will take time.  If actual deadlines are impossible, how can CUs help token holders see progress on growth initiatives as they wait for revenue streams to be actualized? To be fair, I’ve been encouraged by recent reports and status updates such as Off-Chain MIPs Collateral Update: What’s Going On or Clarification on PECU Initiatives & Priorities.  I think we could use some consolidation as it’s hard to read all the updates from all the different core units and get a good picture of what actually matters, how much it matters, when it will matter.  But I have come to understand a little better all that is going on and at this point, I’m willing to be a little more patient. There are still issues to be addressed but I don’t pretend to have the solutions.  I think the centralized voting power is a big one that needs to be resolved at some point (maybe some way to convince exchanges to make a way to delegate).  I think a global budget cap would help force hard but necessary decisions to be made.  But I haven’t really thought through these things and I believe the community can come up with a good plan as long as these issues are acknowledged.

content.content: Traster_Tray:  Maker got started on the back of investors who saw potential in using crypto native assets as collateral. The promise was that smart contracts put in place would be able to create a super efficient lending system. Profits would then be returned to token holders using the buyback and burn model.   Thank you for sharing this thoughtful post. The section quoted above kind of surprised me because I never heard the origin story put quite this way in all my years of following the project since inception, and much more so since becoming a Recognized Delegate in December 2021 (including IRL conversations with early DAO members at ETHDenver). I thought the organizing purpose of MakerDAO was to provide a decentralized algorithmic stablecoin to the world at a time when others were offering centralized asset backed (or reserve backed) solutions. Even today, the makerdao.com website boasts: A better, smarter currency | Dai can be used by anyone, anywhere, anytime. Admittedly, the precise function of MKR the token and incentives for the token holders in the ecosystem had always been a bit mysterious and opaque from an outsider perspective. That said, your comments shed quite a bit of light for me on the sentiments around buyback and burn. Can you say more about where the mission of providing DAI as a currency fits in with the original promises that feel broken today? In theory, would the OG crew support a different mechanism that could do more to fulfill a vision where DAI is an essential and significant DeFi infrastructure asset in the coming phase of worldwide adoption - real world, tradfi, degens and all (too widely distributed, too decentralized, too dominant to fail!)? Whether there is such a better mechanism is currently up for debate, but I think here is the rub. In my mind, as we realize such a grand vision there’s no scenario where MKR number does NOT go up! It’s a very different investment thesis than where things started it seems. Is it possible to consider change without feeling that promises are broken and frustrated? It is a DAO after all. And by golly, look at the world today vs 2017! The only thing certain is change.

content.content: Good point!  I completely left out the stablecoin aspect because honestly, what interested me most from the start as an investor was the fact that stability fees and liquidations get funneled back into the MKR token’s value.  Perhaps that was a narrowly focused way of viewing things but that was where I and I believe many other investors saw the most value.  It certainly wasn’t governance and based on participation levels, I’d venture to say it still isn’t.  Even now, for me, the value of the token is found in the hope that after a growth period, much greater future profits will one day be returned to token holders.  I’m open to being wrong…where do you find value in the MKR token? To answer your question as to where DAI fits in, I’m happy that a product of all this is a decentralized token pegged to the dollar.  I watch with intrigue as all the defi applications continue to develop and grow.  This certainly has been a success.  But if this was the goal, couldn’t you do away with the MKR token and simply have DAI backed with collateral with fees going to a surplus buffer which becomes the backstop for unexpected losses?  Well, I guess this has been the goal because it is actually almost exactly what we have right now. Without the buyback, MKR’s main function is for decentralized governance of the protocol - a function that is not properly in effect and is centralized to a small group of actors.  It also acts as a final last resort option to recoup value if the surplus buffer is exhausted.  So why would one invest in a token where you get only downside risk and seemingly ineffective voting power?  Only if you were convinced into believing it represented the value of the protocol - that if the protocol’s cash flow grows, your cash flow (either present or future) will grow.  But if there’s no present return or trustworthy promise of a future return, then your token is now disconnected from the value of the protocol and there’s no financial reason to hold it.

content.content: While it is a wonderful idea to distribute profits directly to MKR holders, time and especially the market shows that nothing works without big growth, I regularly watch the Governance and Risk Episodes, go through the documents to understand where MakerDAO is at the moment. Without growth you run the risk of oblivion, and I think most people share that thought, which is why there wouldn’t be this drive to grow much more aggressively in the past, the protocol has great products but seems to be struggling to attract enough users, no Marketing and Communication CU, Growth CU is currently doing most of the work, which is good. I think the transparency of some CU is very good, but unfortunately there are no hard facts on how much added value each CU brings to the protocol. I think it is important to identify bad CU and get rid of them in time. Like for example CU Offboarding I don’t want to imply that there are more bad CU, but that the evaluation is so important for each CU. And CU should not lock themselves in, if more people are needed they should hire more people, I think the more people work for the DAO the better, because they automatically become members and are interested in sustainable continuity. You don’t have to promise thousands of MKRs right away - you can start with an internship, which is a great way to get started. CU should not feel that control is necessary all the time, that’s what the facilitators are for, and CU should not feel that they have to beg for money, it’s a healthy debate how much budget is needed in the end, if it’s necessary it will prevail. This also brings us to the critical point of governance, as you also mentioned, there is little incentive at the moment to participate in the voting process so that the DAO is not corrupted by bad CUs and too high costs, even though there are many proposals to improve the system, there are unfortunately no deadlines for many CUs. I think we should put forward a proposal for a redesign of tokenomics and governance with a deadline, because there are few results on these open questions. There have been many proposals for a redesign of tokenomics but nothing is happening, in a vote we can determine which of these proposals is best or a combination of different proposals could be a solution for example.

content.content: personal views only I appreciate everyone’s constructiveness in this post. Hopefully we can get a concrete outcome from the discussion. There are many specific comments in this thread, some of which are paraphrased:  There is a perception that expenses are ballooning out of pace with growth Governance is either centralized or apathetic or both Core Units benefit from information asymmetry to conceal inefficiency and have no formal responsibility towards DAO token holders  I will try and summarize as many of the above as I can in trying to answer the below question:  What should the fundamental goal of a DAO be? My own framework for how I believe DAO work should be conducted speaks to some of the above concerns and is summarized in this post as  Rule 1: The goal of a DAO is to maximize long-term token holder value.  I contend “the goal of a DAO is to maximize long-term token holder value” is the clearest framing for a guiding principle for every core unit collaborator. Why?  The DAO exists and serves exclusively at the pleasure of its token holders To the extent that token holders represent at the very least governance power: Imagine all the holders sold and a hostile takeover took place. The new single holder would control the budget, multisigs, etc and could terminate all the core units and redistribute the surplus buffer to itself. At time of writing the market price of ca. $1900 per token buys equivalent book value of ca. $80 per token, so this redistribution would be horrifically unprofitable. This might not always be the case, and should anyway be the token holder’s prerogative. In practice, therefore, the DAO exists thanks to its token holders.     Traster_Tray:  So why would one invest in a token where you get only downside risk and seemingly ineffective voting power? Only if you were convinced into believing it represented the value of the protocol - that if the protocol’s cash flow grows, your cash flow (either present or future) will grow. But if there’s no present return or trustworthy promise of a future return, then your token is now disconnected from the value of the protocol and there’s no financial reason to hold it.   How do we as CUs answer @Traster_Tray 's concern?  As CU workers we owe a primary ethical responsibility to serve the interests of our token holders DAOs have many advantages to traditional organizations. However, they lack formal structures for fiduciary responsibility and corporate governance. Many of the transactions in the DAO are governed by explicit contracts. These are enforceable in some respect. Either a smart contract executes under given parameters or a governance MIP gets implemented. The challenge for token holders is that their contracts are almost entirely implicit. Tokens have voting rights and the power to appoint delegates. However, delegates (and token holders they represent) are at an informational disadvantage relative to Core Units. Token holders do not have an explicit contract framing their right to participate in price appreciation. However, the heat of the discussions on the forum suggests that many, if not most, token holders are implicitly holding MKR primarily on the expectation it will eventually increase in value. I would be interested to hear from token holders who don’t have this expectation, to ask what level of price drawdown they would be comfortable with, provided another  goal was achieved. To the extent token holders implicitly hold MKR for this reason, the ethical responsibility of the DAO should therefore be to help them achieve this aim. You can frame this as a moral obligation to protect the most junior claim on the surplus buffer return waterfall. In the absence of an explicit contract guiding our work, faced with conflicting decisions or choices on what to do, how fast to do it, or how much to focus on it, to succeed as a DAO we should aim to always respect the implicit contract the token holders have with the DAO. We should therefore aim at every turn to maximize the long-term value to token holders.  If Core Units are empowered by token holders to work against a mandate, they should be trusted until they are not The flipside is that Core Units, as mandated agents on behalf of token holder principals, should be able to execute without micromanagement. Delegates and active token holders can help add value to the protocol within the limitations of their roles. @Doo_StableLab summarized some thoughts, that I echo, in his delegate platform post:    Doo Delegate Platform   "Good Director knows they only have two jobs:  Hire and compensate the right CEO. Approve the budget and strategic plan.  Bad Director thinks their main job is to provide good ideas. They think the board’s job is to micro-manage the CEO." Which can be translated as onboard and compensate the right CUs and approve the budget and strategic plan. "Good Director trusts the CEO completely until they don’t. Once they don’t, it is time to make a change. There’s no in between. Bad Director constantly tests and scrutinizes the CEO, making them feel insecure in their role and always on the brink of being fired." I am probably guilty of it. Will try to be less scrutinizing. "Good Director knows that management can only focus on 1-2 things at once. Bad Director forwards an article they read with the subject line: “Why Aren’t We Doing THIS?!?!”" Come to think of it, I think many of us make this mistake to CUs. "Good Director always remembers that they are a fiduciary of all shareholders. Bad Director looks at every decision as: “What is in it for my firm/pocketbook?”" Very true that delegates should make decisions that ultimately support the Maker system and MKR holders.   Token holders entrust CUs to execute a mandate. They should trust them to execute faithfully against this mandate and should be able to believe they will aim to maximize the long-term value of the token. They should also understand that it is an impractical expectation for everything to be done at the same time. To manage the expectation, CUs would help themselves by communicating about blocks and barriers and see whether token holders are able to help to remove these. Furthermore, there are support functions that add more value than they cost the protocol through efficiency to operations, while not being immediately evident or monetizable. This is worth keeping in mind as we examine budget requests. To the extent trust is lost in a CU, they should be offboarded. It helps nobody to live under a constant state of paranoia. But the token holder really needs to be sure the alternative will help them achieve long-term token holder value better or faster.  What does this mean day-to-day? CUs should act like and show that they are permanently obsessed with the goal of maximizing long-term token holder value, for whatever mission it is that MKR token holders choose to pursue. The flipside is that token holders should trust that CUs are working towards maximizing long-term value. Token holders should provide constructive feedback or find ways to help remove barriers or blocks to progress. If CUs are not satisfied with the pressure from overbearing token holders or feel they are costing more value than they add: they have a duty to their token holders and to themselves to resign and find another working arrangement that meets their goals. If token holders are permanently unsatisfied with CEO/CU performance: they have a duty to themselves to offboard them, find a suitable alternative, or propose to step in themselves to meet their objectives.  In summary: Principal-agent problems make organizations work across us vs them lines. Managing implicit contracts through an ethical framing makes it clear that it is really an us+us vs the market. We should therefore aim at every turn to maximize the long-term value to token holders.

content.content: ACREinvest:  It is a DAO after all. And by golly, look at the world today vs 2017! The only thing certain is change.   This so very true!

I don’t disagree that governance (in the fiduciary, corporate governance sense) as currently structured is not ideal. There are many inefficiencies which exacerbate the principal-agent problem.     SelenaPotter:  But “if token holders don’t like it, they should do something” is a really bad take.   I am not suggesting this in isolation. I am referring to the dearth of explicit rules that are creating this confusion. With or without clarity on these rules, CUs should feel responsible first and foremost for the token holder. Without the token holder there is no DAO. In return the token holder can be expected also to look after their own interests if they feel their interests are being violated. I think we misunderstand each other and are pointing at the same thing. Governance concentration is a second order effect and I agree that smaller token holders are even further down in the returns waterfall than larger token holders (given their comparative inability to influence events). Therefore merit attention also on behalf of larger tokenholders, who should care for the interests of all MKR holders. What do we do? Hasu’s delegate platform proposes one alternative, simple fixes. I am personally a fan. There are other more comprehensive alternatives. It really is ultimately up to the token holders to decide what alternative serves their objectives in the best way. I encourage you to vote or delegate your tokens to make sure your voice, however small, is correctly represented. I’m happy to help to the extent I can if it means the protocol will work better, faster and deliver more value to token holders.

content.content: I sympathised with some of the points raised in @Traster_Tray’s original letter but I think some of the subsequent comments and sentiments seem to lose sight of just how successful the protocol has been (largely through the efforts of the CUs and full-time workers) when you take a step back. Overall, I just don’t see the logic in subscribing to some kind of disaster narrative about the state of Maker. DAI has the most integrations of any decentralised stablecoin across DeFi (and the total supply has 7xed or something in 12 months). There has never been a serious hack or fault in the protocol’s architecture. The protocol is genuinely run by a decentralised collection of contributors (not the sham decentralisation on display in many other projects). And of course, Maker is actually profitable (a rare sight indeed in crypto). By almost every metric, Maker is an unlikely success story. Of course, tokenholders should be careful and diligent when evaluating CU budget requests. But I don’t think there is much actual evidence of an “unsustainable” or exponential rise in costs or waste. Similarly, while I agree there’s new thinking about the protocol and how it should develop in the future, I don’t think it’s plausible to argue that CUs are imposing any kind of new approach unilaterally. The forum is absolutely full of proposals, plans and strategies that are put to the community for input (including signal votes that you don’t need a large MKR stash in order to have a meaningful vote in). Finally, I struggle with the notion that Maker changing focus or direction - in itself - is a problem. This is a relatively old protocol operating in an incredibly dynamic, fluid space. Both delegates and CUs would be doing a disservice to Maker if they weren’t constantly re-evaluating and reassessing in light of changes in the wider ecosystem. I completely agree that there should be open discussion and transparency around these big questions (like what to do with the MKR burn), but that’s exactly what I see: Against the burn, stkMKR: Maker Staking and Tokenomics Revision - #54 by ACREinvest, etc.

content.content: I’m happy to see constructive discussion and a particular thank you to @adcv for your summary and response.  It is interesting to see all the different threads of ideas.  Here are a few more thoughts.  On encouraging small token holders to delegate I think the biggest barrier here is the discomfort many have in leaving the centralized exchanges.  Whether because of fear of hacks, laziness, apathy, or lack of knowledge, exchanges are the easiest way to buy and hold mkr.  Even if there is motivation to be involved, 15-20 MKR is no small sum to the average holder.  Leaving an exchange presents risk and feels like unexplored territory with scary uncertainties.  When you see another account with 70k+ MKR being delegated, it is very demotivating to do the work and pay the fees to transfer out of an exchange.  I believe the greatest source of enablement would be if exchanges implemented delegation.  I don’t know how to incentivize them to do that.  On growth and the surplus buffer. Some people are stuck on the fact that we currently have no buyback and burn and others are arguing passionately about growth.  I want to reframe the conversation by saying this isn’t about whether we should reinstate buyback or whether we should focus on growth.  It’s clear we are headed in the direction of growth and most are onboard with this.  Investors often have a short term focus but those that do have probably already sold their MKR.  This is about trust that growth will actually result in greater future return of capital.  The present value of the token can actually increase if future prospects are visibly bright.  But token holders must trust that there will be a day when capital will be returned.  On the sustainability of rising expenses. Part of this is the appreciation for MKR’s profitability.  Many businesses in growth mode run at a loss and perhaps this is where MKR is headed.  What contributes to the perception of unsustainability is how rapidly these expenses have risen while revenues have been stuck or decreasing.  What contributes to perception of waste is the lack of value or potential found in the details of said expenditures. As you go from being highly profitable to unprofitable, it is natural to feel angst as profitability is often central to an investment theses.  As long as you stay profitable, you have time to experiment without risk of solvency.  Of course, profitability needs to be balanced with competitive pressures, so the question now becomes how effective your spending is.  It is encouraging to see some of the delegates questioning budgets and seeking more fiscal discipline.  For MKR, where we’ve actually tied our growth to the SB (I guess we’re calling it SS now?), expenses hit doubly hard as a decreasing SB would impact growth prospects.  On changes in focus/direction I agree that change can be good and necessary and as I stated before, I’m now totally onboard with focus on growth.  What’s important is how change is communicated and how it is done.  The shift from burning to growth was very controversial and could have been better.  People were onboard with implementing the SB to reduce risk and then onboard with increasing the limit further to reduce risk.  These requests were voted on with stated intention to reduce risk but there was always an end in sight and as the cap continued to be lifted, it grew more controversial.  Then there was a compromise of partial burning that ended with the 250 million cap that was approved quickly because of the recent liquidation problem.  Finally, burning is now indefinitely on hold as focus has shifted to growth.  These changes in policy were done successively and often when the end for SB building was in sight and anticipation for the burn was building.  If we had simply argued for stopping the burn from the get go for growth purposes and that path was rationally discussed/chosen by the community, the sense of moving goal posts or ulterior motives would not be as strong.  You couple this with an unexpected rise in operating expenses which is in direct competition with the burn or potential for a burn, and you can see how many, who had the burn as part of their central investment theses, felt misled. I promised to move on from this but I think recognition of what happened is helpful in rebuilding trust.

YES! @Traster_Tray wen “Meet Your Delegate” zoom?

Let me preface this by saying I’m 100% biased given that the SF Core Unit reports expenses; but I cannot get onboard with this narrative of “unsustainable rising expenses.” I’m not singling out this post of thread, but have seen this misconception repeated in multiple places. Perhaps some are unfamiliar with the SF Core Unit or our work, but we post expense and financial reports for the DAO, every month in a concise report to provide visibility. Search “expense-reporting” on the forums and you will see every month’s report since we started in September. Expenses having certainly increased since then, but we’ve nearly doubled the number of Core Units as well and have almost certainly doubled headcount. What will drive the long-term success of this project more than anything is the human capital that works for it - whether that’s on a full-time, part-time, or even as a casual DAO member, everyone can contribute. To bring on the best talent, they need to be compensated and motivated to perform. The MKR compensation plan(s) aren’t perfect, but they ensure CUs have ‘skin in the game’ and are motivated to act in the best interests of MKR holders (since they are one). Should there be a performance component or modifier? IMO, yes, but it has been extremely difficult for the DAO to find consensus on anything involving MKR comp (see the myriad of different plans and resistance to standardize). Back to the spend - I’ve seen misinformation being spread recently regarding expenses, unprofitability, and rising expenses, but the reality is that our burn rate has actually been decreasing recently. Our annualized DAI burn rate was $54.9M in December, $42M in January, and $41.4M in February, largely driven by a reduction in forecasted Oracle expenses. Over the past month, our SF revenue has been floating between $75-85M, giving us roughly 50% operating margin. To benchmark this, Nasdaq companies collectively had operating and net margins of ~24% and 20% last year. Those companies would kill for our margins. Yes, we are a nascent business and our revenue streams are highly volatile, but we are not in the dire straits some have intimated. Here’s a cash flow scenario analysis we performed last month which breaks out the drivers and different scenarios which could lead to breakeven or negative income (drawing from the surplus buffer).  image1387×959 268 KB  Even so, I agree with the premise that we must be prudent on spend and that it’s unclear what value is being created by some Core Units. This is why I’ve pushed hard for CU performance evaluations and believe they are critical to scaling the DAO long-term. There is already an inordinate amount of Governance overhead and frankly impossible to keep up with everything even as a full-time member of the DAO. Lastly, I understand where you’re coming from. I joined the DAO as a small MKR holder and even officially represented the small MKR holders in the first MKR compensation working group. I was disenfranchised at times and also frustrated by the lack of transparency around spend. So, I started working on tracking spend part-time and started building and iterating on more and more financial reports to improve transparency, culminating in full-time commitment to this project. I’ll close by saying that I deeply encourage you to stay involved and become more involved in the DAO. You’ve got a pulse on how many are feeling and don’t sell yourself short on what you can achieve. “Be the change you wish to see in the world”

Financial Report 2022-03 Strategic Finance   Financial Report 2022-03 Hello all, new mixtape from @strat-fin-core-unit dropping. The financial report for March 2022 is available here.  Please let us know your thoughts and comments on these pages.   Summary Overall Net Protocol Income was 2.7M DAI, -44% from February and -69% from March 2021. Annualized ROE has held stable at around 90%.  Volatility is high in this market. To weather it, we need to nurture and grow our whales, increase the frequency with which the DAO’s makes revenue-gener…     We ping the CUs every month for an itemized breakdown of all the expenses and publish expense transparency reports thereafter. We’re seeing a lot of month on month underspend relative to budgets. We do not consider budgeted but unspent expenses to have ‘left’ the system and we actually add Dai sitting in wallets to a total surplus buffer figure. We are assuming CU wallets are junior to the surplus buffer in the event of a serious drawdown. Regarding margin maintenance, there is a case for temporarily reduced margins given ongoing investments in growth. The difference with the blockchain accounting universe is it is impractical to break-out capex vs opex, or even in many instances accrual vs cash accounting. So it all looks like it’s hitting the surplus buffer immediately, although the benefits may be some way away that would ‘artificially’ pump the margin. Please bear this whiplash effect in mind as you review month-on-month figures. For this reason we take a 6mo rolling average window to calculate ROE or it would be nonsensical.
